name: NBCNews
text: Nearly 8 years after Superstorm Sandy, residents of The Ironbound in Newark, New Jersey, are surrounded by a highly contaminated Superfund site, fearing the long-term health consequences of water and muck that swept into their homes. (1/6) #NBCNewsThreads https://t.co/mJCgkHh1Ks

name: NBCNews
text: Activist Arnold Cohen organized marches calling for investigations into the toxic waste site in the 1980s, which re… https://t.co/aLRjdD5Jne

name: NBCNews
text: Local advocate Anna Baptista attended those marches when she was young and still fights for those whose homes were… https://t.co/65s4CQc1I7

name: NBCNews
text: Diabetes, hypertension, and higher rates of lead poisoning in children are some of the health problems that could b… https://t.co/3RL52nLXS8

name: NBCNews
text: After decades of unhampered pollution, the Ironbound Community Corp., a local nonprofit, helped pass a state bill that requires companies to receive approval if their operations are heavily affecting the environment and communities around them. (5/6) https://t.co/yWehHAPkd0

name: NBCNews
text:
While the bill may prevent further pollution, people in damaged sites like Passaic still worry about their health — particularly in the event of another mega storm.

Baptista still wonders: “What will happen when the next big flood comes?” (6/6)
https://t.co/yWehHAxJls
